image.altText: Building erupts into flames in Gaza

items.synopsis: Palestinian militants launch a major attack against Israel, prompting Israel's military to strike targets in the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: Israel cuts power to Gaza as Hamas takes dozens of soldiers and civilians hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been on Insiders this morning. Here's what he had to say on the situation in Israel and Gaza. "This is an abhorrent attack on Israel. This is indiscriminate, civilians being targeted, killed and murdered and many are being taken as hostages. "This is a dreadful circumstance that people didn't see coming, wasn't foreshadowed, a shock attack. "This action is ongoing. It must stop. Israel has a right to defend itself, which is what it is doing." Mr Albanese said: "Of course people worry about escalation but Israel has a right to defend itself and it will be doing so." "This is an attack on Israel by Hamas that has no precedent for what is occurring here." He said he believed all Australians were safe. "There are Australian Defence Force personnel, in the region, and at this point in time the advice ... is that no Australians are caught up. It's incomplete advice, this has been a very dark 24 hours."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese: 'Israel has a right to defend itself'

children.content: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been on Insiders this morning.
Here's what he had to say on the situation in Israel and Gaza.
"This is an abhorrent attack on Israel. This is indiscriminate, civilians being targeted, killed and murdered and many are being taken as hostages.
"This is a dreadful circumstance that people didn't see coming, wasn't foreshadowed, a shock attack.
"This action is ongoing. It must stop. Israel has a right to defend itself, which is what it is doing."
Mr Albanese said: "Of course people worry about escalation but Israel has a right to defend itself and it will be doing so."
"This is an attack on Israel by Hamas that has no precedent for what is occurring here."
He said he believed
all Australians were safe.

"There are Australian Defence Force personnel, in the region, and at this point in time the advice ... is that no Australians are caught up. It's incomplete advice, this has been a very dark 24 hours."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former Australian ambassador to Israel Dave Sharma has spoken to the ABC, saying "clearly this was a very large failure" of Israeli intelligence services. "Israel clearly did not see this coming," he said. "The fact Hamas went in both on the ground, by breaking through the border fence, by air, using motorised vehicles, and by sea as well and were able to hold and occupy and run rampant throughout many small Israeli towns in the south for several hours before the Israeli Defence Forces mounted a response shows you they had no idea whatsoever this was coming." Watch the full video here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: This is a 'large failure' of Israeli intelligence

children.content: Former Australian ambassador to Israel Dave Sharma has spoken to the ABC, saying "clearly this was a very large failure" of Israeli intelligence services.
"Israel clearly did not see this coming," he said.

"The fact Hamas went in both on the ground, by breaking through the border fence, by air, using motorised vehicles, and by sea as well and were able to hold and occupy and run rampant throughout many small Israeli towns in the south for several hours before the Israeli Defence Forces mounted a response shows you they had no idea whatsoever this was coming."
Watch the full video here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel will stop supplying electricity, fuel and goods to Gaza, according to a statement from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. Israel shut down the electricity supply earlier in the day and much of Gaza is now in darkness. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel will cut off supplies to Gaza

children.content: Israel will stop supplying
electricity, fuel and goods
to Gaza, according to a statement from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office.
Israel shut down the electricity supply earlier in the day and much of Gaza is now in darkness.
AP

image.altText: Palestine tower in Gaza city collapses

items.synopsis: Israel says it is now at war with Hamas, launching air strikes on Gaza and vowing to inflict an "unprecedented price" after dozens of Hamas militants broke out of the blockaded Gaza Strip and into nearby Israeli towns, killing hundreds and abducting others in an unprecedented operation.

title.children: 'We are at war': Israel retaliates with Gaza strikes after Palestinian militants kill hundreds and take hostages

image.altText: Palestinians wave their national flag and celebrate.

items.synopsis: Israel is responding to the biggest Hamas attack in years, but the seeds of the unrest were sown decades ago.

title.children: Israel and Hamas 'at war': How did we get here and how is it playing out?

image.altText: Colleen Johnstone and Phil Bayley with their son Angus using a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: Angus isn't like most other year 11 students — it takes him a lot longer to read and understand information. His school gave him extra time at his mid-year exams which really helped. The trouble is, at finals, he won't get anywhere near that — and experts say that isn't fair.

title.children: Angus needs more time in exams to help his 'brain think', but he won't get it at his finals — and advocates say that's unfair

items.synopsis: Australian law enforcement has started solving missing persons and unidentified remains cases using official police access to private genealogy databases, which combined, hold the DNA records of millions of people around the world.

title.children: It's being called the biggest game-changer in forensic investigations since DNA testing

image.altText: A spacecrafts solar panel is visible in the foreground, a large grey orange asteroid in the background

items.synopsis: The Psyche mission will travel to an asteroid unlike any we've seen. Its investigations could shed light on how the Solar System and the planets formed.

title.children: This asteroid, worth an estimated $15,600 quadrillion, is the target of a new NASA mission

image.altText: A woman stands next to a busy street while wearing headphones.

items.synopsis: The "silent walking" trend on TikTok has highlighted how much we rely on audio distractions to get us through the day. But is it a problem?

title.children: 'Me and my thoughts? Sounds horrible': What the 'silent walking' trend says about us

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent, Casey Briggs writes.

title.children: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

image.altText: An elderly woman in a red headscarf stands in front of a wall of family photos

items.synopsis: Aunty Ruth Hegarty lived through a cruel chapter in Australian history. Now aged 94, she's approaching the Voice vote with optimism for future generations.

title.children: 'This is truth-telling': At 94, Ruth Hegarty wants to you to hear her story before you vote

image.altText: A car park with an area taped off and police in attendance.

items.synopsis: Police say the gunmen involved in yesterday's deadly shooting at a shopping centre in Melbourne's north remain on the run, as detectives investigate whether the discovery of a second burnt-out car is linked to the crime.

title.children: Gunmen on the run after shooting at car park in Melbourne's north

image.altText: A photo of a man and a woman with their faces scribbled out.

items.synopsis: A letter from a stranger is all it took to spiral Martin into losing control of his own life. The disability royal commission has made recommendations to reform guardianship legislation, including gag laws that prevent Martin from speaking about his experience.

title.children: We can't show you their faces — a royal commission says that needs to change

image.altText: Two men sitting at a table, smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: Before he became Ukraine's commander-in-chief, Volodymyr Zelenskyy was never far from the front lines — these men were there with him, and know a different side to the president.

title.children: The men who know a different side to Volodymyr Zelenzkyy

image.altText: Vertical gardens and a fountain.

items.synopsis: Singapore will soon join Dubai to provide travellers with a more efficient immigration clearance as early as 2024 following an update to its Immigration Bill.

title.children: Singapore to go passport-free but what are the risks and could Australia follow suit?

image.altText: Jamie Whincup at Bathurst

items.synopsis: The Bathurst 1000 sees the Gen3 Supercars take to the mountain on the 60th anniversary of the great race. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Bathurst 1000 has a clean start as Whincup leads

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We are on lap 9 already. My word time can go quickly! Whincup is closing in a lead of one second over Russell. Golding — he is driving a very nice race so far — is another second back in third place. This is normal. Following very closely to another car can have bad consequences. The hot, dirty air that comes off the back of a car goes into the front of the trailing car. The hot air causes problems for tyres and brakes. So Russell dropping back one second behind Whincup is most likely a deliberate move.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 10: Gaps starting to open at the front

children.content: We are on lap 9 already. My word time can go quickly!
Whincup is closing in a lead of one second over Russell.
Golding — he is driving a very nice race so far — is another second back in third place.
This is normal. Following very closely to another car can have bad consequences.
The hot, dirty air that comes off the back of a car goes into the front of the trailing car.
The hot air causes problems for tyres and brakes.
So Russell dropping back one second behind Whincup is most likely a deliberate move.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Will Brown! Keep going my man. He started 17th, which is out of position for that Erebus car he is driving. And Will is showing he really should be upfront. He has made up nine places to start the race.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lap 7: Will Brown is on fire, climbing nine spots

children.content: Will Brown! Keep going my man.
He started 17th, which is out of position for that Erebus car he is driving.
And Will is showing he really should be upfront.
He has made up nine places to start the race.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lights go out and it's a good start for Jaime Whincup. He takes the lead into the first corner. Russell didn't have a bad start from pole, but it just wasn't as good as the Australian racing legend.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lights out — the Bathurst 1000 is GO!

children.content: Lights go out and it's a good start for
Jaime Whincup
He takes the lead into the first corner.
Russell didn't have a bad start from pole, but it just wasn't as good as the Australian racing legend.

items.synopsis: Dean has fallen in love with the elusive Tasmanian azure kingfisher, but fears not enough is being done to protect the species, which is one of 14 endangered native birds without a recovery plan.

title.children: It's estimated there are between 250 and 400 of these birds left in the wild — but there's no plan to save them

title.children: Siskaeee is risking jail and defying the haters to make OnlyFans content in Indonesia. Here's why

image.altText: A man holding his licence in a park

items.synopsis: When Ben was scammed out of footy tickets, he had no idea the people who duped him were about to use his identity to ruin his reputation and scam even more people — including those desperate for Taylor Swift tickets.

title.children: Ben barely knows Taylor Swift's music, but people falsely believe he scammed the artist's concert tickets

image.altText: A mother sits on a rug with her four of her children as they read and write on white sheets of paper.
